sense.name: a measurable position along a quantitative scale
sense.examples: It is said that there are only 7 degrees of social separation between any two people in the world. The glacier moved down the mountain a few degrees each year. The degree of color saturation is controlled by this slider in the color editing window.

sense.name: an academic title or rank, based on completion of curriculum
sense.examples: John earned an advanced degree in molecular biology. The poet was awarded an honorary degree by an Ivy League institution. Her daughter is going for an undergraduate degree in computer science.

sense.name: the measurement of an angle or arc
sense.examples: I'd say the incline of that plane is about 45 degrees. The aerobatics pilot performed a turn of 180 degrees. The navigator showed us that we were 1 degree of latitude off in our course.

sense.name: class of equations sharing highest exponent power of variables
sense.examples: This is an equation of the second degree. Can you solve these third degree equations?

sense.name: a measurement of temperature
sense.examples: Yesterday the high was 85 degrees, Fahrenheit. The students learned the equation for converting degrees in Fahrenheit to degrees in Celsius.

sense.name: the extent of seriousness of some matter or circumstance
sense.examples: The prosecution is arguing that this case is murder in the first degree. The doctor showed the interns the differences between second and third degree burns on patients.

sense.name: an approximate amount of application of something
sense.commentary: DEGREE[+quantity][+measurement][+approximate][+application] Note: related to Sense 1, but does not imply a strict measurable position along a scale
sense.examples: We should exercise some degree of caution in approaching him on this matter. It's a question of degree how much discipline and training an individual dog will require. He has a moderate degree of artistic ability.

sense.name: a little at a time
sense.examples: By degrees the children are beginning to assume responsibility for themselves. We watched the giant ship turning around, by degrees, in the deep channel.

sense.name: to some extent
sense.examples: It is possible to educate oneself, to a degree.

sense.name: to a considerable extent, very much so
sense.commentary: Idiom: to_a_degree Note: Dated usage - compare this sense of 'extreme' to the now more common 'somewhat' of the idiom in Sense 9
sense.examples: The pressure he was put under must have been frustrating to a degree!
